page.title: 03Quarrying and Ecology
page.content: There are several disused serpentine quarries in this area which were worked extensively during World War II.In the spoil heaps around them we found a great variety of serpentine samples of varying colour and hardness.There were also traces of many other minerals.At that time there was little mechanisation and we could see the tracks that the 'bogies' had followed when they were loaded and man-handled down the rough hillside to the pier to await shipment.The surrounding area of the quarries is unimproved heathland with a great variety of wild flowers including the unique Edmondston's Arctic Mouse-ear Chickweed.At Alma there is a disused limestone quarry which was worked over many generations for building purposes The quarry floor was dry and no heather grew on this limestone band.
